00047 #ifndef NT_MERSENNE_TWISTER_EXTERNAL_OBJ_H
00048 #define NT_MERSENNE_TWISTER_EXTERNAL_OBJ_H
00049 
00050 // Not thread safe (unless auto-initialization is avoided and each thread has
00051 // its own MTRand object)
00052 
00053 #include <iostream>
00054 #include <limits.h>
00055 #include <stdio.h>
00056 
00057 
00058 class MTRand {
00059 // Data
00060 public:
00061     typedef unsigned long uint32;  // unsigned integer type, at least 32 bits   
00062     enum { N = 624 };              // length of state vector
00063     enum { SAVE = N + 1 };         // length of array for save()
00064 
00065 protected:
00066     enum { M = 397 };              // period parameter
00067     enum { MAGIC = 0x9908b0dfU };  // magic constant
00068     
00069     uint32 state[N];  // internal state
00070     uint32 *pNext;    // next value to get from state
00071     int left;         // number of values left before reload needed
00072 
00073 
00074 //Methods
00075 public:
00076     MTRand( const uint32& oneSeed );  // initialize with a simple uint32
00077     MTRand( uint32 *const bigSeed );  // initialize with an array of N uint32's
00078     MTRand();  // auto-initialize with /dev/urandom or time() and clock()
00079     
00080     // Access to 32-bit random numbers
00081     // Do NOT use for CRYPTOGRAPHY without securely hashing several returned
00082     // values together, otherwise the generator state can be learned after
00083     // reading 624 consecutive values.
00084     double rand();                          // real number in [0,1]
00085     double rand( const double& n );         // real number in [0,n]
00086     double randExc();                       // real number in [0,1)
00087     double randExc( const double& n );      // real number in [0,n)
00088     double randDblExc();                    // real number in (0,1)
00089     double randDblExc( const double& n );   // real number in (0,n)
00090     uint32 randInt();                       // integer in [0,2^32-1]
00091     uint32 randInt( const uint32& n );      // integer in [0,n] for n < 2^32
00092     double operator()() { return rand(); }  // same as rand()
00093     
00094     // Re-seeding functions with same behavior as initializers
00095     void seed( uint32 oneSeed );
00096     void seed( uint32 *const bigSeed );
00097     void seed();
00098     
00099     // Saving and loading generator state
00100     void save( uint32* saveArray ) const;  // to array of size SAVE
00101     void load( uint32 *const loadArray );  // from such array
00102     friend std::ostream& operator<<( std::ostream& os, const MTRand& mtrand );
00103     friend std::istream& operator>>( std::istream& is, MTRand& mtrand );
00104 
00105 protected:
00106     void reload();
00107     uint32 hiBit( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x80000000U; }
00108     uint32 loBit( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x00000001U; }
00109     uint32 loBits( const uint32& u ) const { return u & 0x7fffffffU; }
00110     uint32 mixBits( const uint32& u, const uint32& v ) const
00111         { return hiBit(u) | loBits(v); }
00112     uint32 twist( const uint32& m, const uint32& s0, const uint32& s1 ) const
00113         { return m ^ (mixBits(s0,s1)>>1) ^ (loBit(s1) ? MAGIC : 0U); }
00114     static uint32 hash( time_t t, clock_t c );
00115 };
00116 
00117 
00118 inline MTRand::MTRand( const uint32& oneSeed )
00119     { seed(oneSeed); }
00120 
00121 inline MTRand::MTRand( uint32 *const bigSeed )
00122     { seed(bigSeed); }
00123 
00124 inline MTRand::MTRand()
00125     { seed(); }
00126 
00127 inline double MTRand::rand()
00128     { return double(randInt()) * 2.3283064370807974e-10; }
00129 
00130 inline double MTRand::rand( const double& n )
00131     { return rand() * n; }
00132 
00133 inline double MTRand::randExc()
00134     { return double(randInt()) * 2.3283064365386963e-10; }
00135 
00136 inline double MTRand::randExc( const double& n )
00137     { return randExc() * n; }
00138 
00139 inline double MTRand::randDblExc()
00140     { return double( 1.0 + randInt() ) * 2.3283064359965952e-10; }
00141 
00142 inline double MTRand::randDblExc( const double& n )
00143     { return randDblExc() * n; }
00144 
00145 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::randInt()
00146 {
00147     if( left == 0 ) reload();
00148     --left;
00149         
00150     register uint32 s1;
00151     s1 = *pNext++;
00152     s1 ^= (s1 >> 11);
00153     s1 ^= (s1 <<  7) & 0x9d2c5680U;
00154     s1 ^= (s1 << 15) & 0xefc60000U;
00155     return ( s1 ^ (s1 >> 18) );
00156 }
00157 
00158 
00159 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::randInt( const uint32& n )
00160 {
00161     // Find which bits are used in n
00162     uint32 used = ~0;
00163     for( uint32 m = n; m; used <<= 1, m >>= 1 ) {}
00164     used = ~used;
00165     
00166     // Draw numbers until one is found in [0,n]
00167     uint32 i;
00168     do
00169         i = randInt() & used;  // toss unused bits to shorten search
00170     while( i > n );
00171     return i;
00172 }
00173 
00174 
00175 inline void MTRand::seed( uint32 oneSeed )
00176 {
00177     // Seed the generator with a simple uint32
00178     register uint32 *s;
00179     register int i;
00180     for( i = N, s = state;
00181          i--;
00182          *s    = oneSeed & 0xffff0000,
00183          *s++ |= ( (oneSeed *= 69069U)++ & 0xffff0000 ) >> 16,
00184          (oneSeed *= 69069U)++ ) {}  // hard to read, but fast
00185     reload();
00186 }
00187 
00188 
00189 inline void MTRand::seed( uint32 *const bigSeed )
00190 {
00191     // Seed the generator with an array of 624 uint32's
00192     // There are 2^19937-1 possible initial states.  This function allows
00193     // any one of those to be chosen by providing 19937 bits.  The lower
00194     // 31 bits of the first element, bigSeed[0], are discarded.  Any bits
00195     // above the lower 32 in each element are also discarded.  Theoretically,
00196     // the rest of the array can contain any values except all zeroes.
00197     // Just call seed() if you want to get array from /dev/urandom
00198     register uint32 *s = state, *b = bigSeed;
00199     register int i = N;
00200     for( ; i--; *s++ = *b++ & 0xffffffff ) {}
00201     reload();
00202 }
00203 
00204 
00205 inline void MTRand::seed()
00206 {
00207     // Seed the generator with an array from /dev/urandom if available
00208     // Otherwise use a hash of time() and clock() values
00209     
00210     // First try getting an array from /dev/urandom
00211     FILE* urandom = fopen( "/dev/urandom", "rb" );
00212     if( urandom )
00213     {
00214         register uint32 *s = state;
00215         register int i = N;
00216         register bool success = true;
00217         while( success && i-- )
00218         {
00219             success = fread( s, sizeof(uint32), 1, urandom );
00220             *s++ &= 0xffffffff;  // filter in case uint32 > 32 bits
00221         }
00222         fclose(urandom);
00223         if( success )
00224         {
00225             // There is a 1 in 2^19937 chance that a working urandom gave
00226             // 19937 consecutive zeroes and will make the generator fail
00227             // Ignore that case and continue with initialization
00228             reload();
00229             return;
00230         }
00231     }
00232     
00233     // Was not successful, so use time() and clock() instead
00234     seed( hash( time(NULL), clock() ) );
00235 }
00236 
00237 
00238 inline void MTRand::reload()
00239 {
00240     // Generate N new values in state
00241     // Made clearer and faster by Matthew Bellew (matthew.bellew@home.com)
00242     register uint32 *p = state;
00243     register int i;
00244     for( i = N - M; i--; ++p )
00245         *p = twist( p[M], p[0], p[1] );
00246     for( i = M; --i; ++p )
00247         *p = twist( p[M-N], p[0], p[1] );
00248     *p = twist( p[M-N], p[0], state[0] );
00249 
00250     left = N, pNext = state;
00251 }
00252 
00253 
00254 inline MTRand::uint32 MTRand::hash( time_t t, clock_t c )
00255 {
00256     // Get a uint32 from t and c
00257     // Better than uint32(x) in case x is floating point in [0,1]
00258     // Based on code by Lawrence Kirby (fred@genesis.demon.co.uk)
00259 
00260     static uint32 differ = 0;  // guarantee time-based seeds will change
00261 
00262     uint32 h1 = 0;
00263     unsigned char *p = (unsigned char *) &t;
00264     for( size_t i = 0; i < sizeof(t); ++i )
00265     {
00266         h1 *= UCHAR_MAX + 2U;
00267         h1 += p[i];
00268     }
00269     uint32 h2 = 0;
00270     p = (unsigned char *) &c;
00271     for( size_t j = 0; j < sizeof(c); ++j )
00272     {
00273         h2 *= UCHAR_MAX + 2U;
00274         h2 += p[j];
00275     }
00276     return ( h1 + differ++ ) ^ h2;
00277 }
00278 
00279 
00280 inline void MTRand::save( uint32* saveArray ) const
00281 {
00282     register uint32 *sa = saveArray;
00283     register const uint32 *s = state;
00284     register int i = N;
00285     for( ; i--; *sa++ = *s++ ) {}
00286     *sa = left;
00287 }
00288 
00289 
00290 inline void MTRand::load( uint32 *const loadArray )
00291 {
00292     register uint32 *s = state;
00293     register uint32 *la = loadArray;
00294     register int i = N;
00295     for( ; i--; *s++ = *la++ ) {}
00296     left = *la;
00297     pNext = &state[N-left];
00298 }
00299 
00300 
00301 inline std::ostream& operator<<( std::ostream& os, const MTRand& mtrand )
00302 {
00303     register const MTRand::uint32 *s = mtrand.state;
00304     register int i = mtrand.N;
00305     for( ; i--; os << *s++ << "\t" ) {}
00306     return os << mtrand.left;
00307 }
00308 
00309 
00310 inline std::istream& operator>>( std::istream& is, MTRand& mtrand )
00311 {
00312     register MTRand::uint32 *s = mtrand.state;
00313     register int i = mtrand.N;
00314     for( ; i--; is >> *s++ ) {}
00315     is >> mtrand.left;
00316     mtrand.pNext = &mtrand.state[mtrand.N-mtrand.left];
00317     return is;
00318 }

00322 // Change log:
00323 //
00324 // v0.1 - First release on 15 May 2000
00325 //      - Based on code by Makoto Matsumoto, Takuji Nishimura, and Shawn Cokus
00326 //      - Translated from C to C++
00327 //      - Made completely ANSI compliant
00328 //      - Designed convenient interface for initialization, seeding, and
00329 //        obtaining numbers in default or user-defined ranges
00330 //      - Added automatic seeding from /dev/urandom or time() and clock()
00331 //      - Provided functions for saving and loading generator state
00332 //
00333 // v0.2 - Fixed bug which reloaded generator one step too late
00334 //
00335 // v0.3 - Switched to clearer, faster reload() code from Matthew Bellew
00336 //
00337 // v0.4 - Removed trailing newline in saved generator format to be consistent
00338 //        with output format of built-in types
00339 //
00340 // v0.5 - Improved portability by replacing static const int's with enum's and
00341 //        clarifying return values in seed(); suggested by Eric Heimburg
00342 //      - Removed MAXINT constant; use 0xffffffff instead
00343 //
00344 // v0.6 - Eliminated seed overflow when uint32 is larger than 32 bits
00345 //      - Changed integer [0,n] generator to give better uniformity
00346 //
00347 // v0.7 - Fixed operator precedence ambiguity in reload()
00348 //      - Added access for real numbers in (0,1) and (0,n)
